> Hi!
> 
> I've got some questions on size of test cases and would like to hear 
> your opinions.

I would suggest moving this discussion to the testdrivendevelopment list, 
since you'll have access to people with more general TDD 
experience/knowledge. (Besides, this isn't really a JUnit question.)

> Now my test methods get quite large. <snip />

First question: is there much raw code duplication in these tests? Start with 
duplication within a single test method -- does removing duplication make the 
test smaller or simpler? Next look at duplication in a collection of test 
methods -- can you factor out duplication from four or five test methods? If 
so, does that make the tests smaller?

Next question: is there conceptual duplication in these tests? Do tests A, B 
and C make essentially the same assertions? You may think you're being 
thorough, but you may be doing too much by asserting the same things in a 
number of tests. I've done this and I'm learning to identify and challenge 
it. Trying moving the duplicated assertions to one test and let the others 
simply assert on what's different, rather than the same old thing.

> Would you rely on some orientation of created tiles, e.g. assume the 
> left turning road is always constructed as from east turning to south 
> (maybe this is like the Blackbox / Whitebox discussion)?

Perhaps this will help get you going until you think of something better. 
Sometimes you have to make assumptions to make the tests workable in size and 
scope. If you have one test that shows that it doesn't matter which 
orientation the left-turning road has, then for the remaining tests, one left-
turning road is as good as another. If that changes, though, then you have to 
remember: aha! The south-to-west road might behave differently! I should add 
a test!

> Would you even allow incomplete tests (not testing what is "most 
> likely working", e.g. assuming a tile does not have special items)?

Test until fear turns to boredom. :)
